qas.question: If a tree starts forming heartwood right away, will its sapwood layer be thin or thick?
What property of heartwood that has nothing to do with how important it is to trees got it its name?
Does a beech tree usually have thin or thick sapwood?
Does a sassafras tree typically have a thin or thick sapwood layer?
Would a thin or a thick sapwood layer be found in a pine tree?

context: The term heartwood derives solely from its <a1_0>position<a1_0/> and not from any vital importance to the tree. This is evidenced by the fact that a tree can thrive with its heart completely decayed. Some species begin to form heartwood very early in life, so having only a <a0_0>thin<a0_0/> layer of live sapwood, while in others the change comes slowly. <a3_0>Thin<a3_0/> sapwood is characteristic of such species as chestnut, black locust, mulberry, osage-orange, and sassafras, while in maple, ash, hickory, hackberry, beech, and pine, <a2_0><a4_0>thick<a4_0/><a2_0/> sapwood is the rule. Others never form heartwood.
